projects.description: My first JavaScript program, where I first learned how to dynamically render webpages. This project serves up pages with randomly-selected inspirational quotes. Updates automatically based on a timer. The visitor also has the option of updating the displayed quote with the click of a button.

My second JavaScript program, emphasizing using JavaScript to implement pagination on a webpage when displaying a series of HTML objects. Here we have a mockup employee directory where only nine employees are displayed per page. The visitor can filter the employees shown by searching for a pattern string in the Search Bar at the top.

My third JavaScript program, emulating an interactive event registration form. User input (contact and billing info) is validated using regex. Also some menu options dynamically update depending on what the user selects from the form. Form submission is only allowed once all inputs have been validated.

My fourth JavaScript program. A Phrase Guessing game, like Wheel of Fortune but without the wheel. The on-screen keyboard updates as the user guesses letters to compose the phrase, and 'lives' are lost with wrong guesses. Built with Object Oriented Programming principles.

This JavaScript program hearkens back to the mockup employee directory from Project 2. The difference here is that instead of loading a static list of employees from a local data file, the app is served a dynamic array of employee data from https://randomuser.me via an asynchronous API call. In addition, when you click an employee's panel, a popup window appears with additional demographic information.

Do you like self-reference? I built this website with Node, Express, and Pug to serve a combination of both static and dynamic content. It features an "About Me" page and current list of completed and published JavaScript projects. The website also mentions the technologies used to complete each project, with a "live link" to the rendered project. I also figured out how to host this Node.js project on Heroku, which I think is pretty cool. Thank you for visiting!
